results.title: The Northern Renaissance
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The love of minutely observed detail is one of the characteristics that distinguishes the art of the Northern Renaissance from that of Italy. Although the Italians too, studied the surfaces of things, their intent was to work from the inner form outwards, seeking an organising principle or harmony outlying outward appearances. It is in the work of Jan van Eyck and the master Albrecht Durer, that the style of the Northern Renaissance is best showcased.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Early Renaissance of Italy
results.creator_credit: Mick Gold, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Covers the revival and reinterpretation of the classical tradition in the works of Florentine artists Masaccio, Donatello, and Ghiberti. Discusses how these artists exemplify the merging of Christian and humanistic values. Examines the realism of Jan van Eyck and the spiritual crisis of Northern Europe as revealed in Gruenwald’s Isenheim altarpiece. Discusses the spirit of the Renaissance as reflected in Durer’s work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mick Gold, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Age of the gothic
results.creator_credit: Perry Miller Adato, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Chartres Cathedral is one of the greatest of all Medieval structures. Gothic architecture exploits the advantages of the construction techniques of the “flying buttress” which permitted lighter internal walls with large areas of glass. The Gothic style reflected the new age of humanism which arose from the economic and political stability in Western Europe between 100 and 1300 AD.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Perry Miller Adato, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: A White garment of churches
results.creator_credit: Perry Miller Adato, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Examines Romanesque and Gothic churches as evidence of the values of the society that created them. Shows the effect of monasticism and pilgrimage on Romanesque church architecture. Gothic architecture and sculpture, exemplified in the churches of Chatres and St Denis, are discussed as evidence of a new theology and profound changes in medieval society. As most people, including Kings and Queens could not write, the visual images of Christian art were called “Books of the illiterate”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Perry Miller Adato, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Imperial stone: the art of Rome
results.creator_credit: Bayley Silleck, Channel Four, TVS and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Michael Wood and Richard Brilliant look at Roman architecture which embodied the austere ideals of this conquering empire. The discovery and use of concrete and the development of architectural forms based on the keystone arch is highlighted as these had a significant effect on building design in Europe. The Panthenon is seen as a landmark structure and the transition of pagan symbols and forms into Early Christian society is discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bayley Silleck, Channel Four, TVS and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Legacy of Greece
results.creator_credit: Bayley Silleck, Geoff Dunlop, Channel 4, TVS and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The orgins of humanism and much of Western art can be traced back to Ancient Greece. The development of sculpture, from the archaic, through to classical and the the later more elaborate hellenistic style is discussed by looking at examples of change in the Kouroi and Korai figures. Highlights the perfection reached in architecture, as exemplified by the Parthenon as well as the classic art of pottery decoration in the famous red and black figure vases.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bayley Silleck, Geoff Dunlop, Channel 4, TVS and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

Highlights the perfection reached in architecture, as exemplified by the Parthenon as well as the classic art of pottery decoration in the famous red and black figure vases.

Episode number 1 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The orgins of humanism and much of Western art can be traced back to Ancient Greece. The development of sculpture, from the archaic, through to classical and the the later more elaborate hellenistic style is discussed by looking at examples of change in the Kouroi and Korai figures. Highlights the perfection reached in architecture, as exemplified by the Parthenon as well as the classic art of pottery decoration in the famous red and black figure vases.

results.title: In our own time
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Bauman and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on art work from the Abstract Impressionists to the Pop artists of the 21st century. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the works of such artists as Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and Klaus Oldenburg, tracing the progression of New York as a centre for the visual arts and the development of Pop Art. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: Into the Twentieth Century
results.creator_credit: Ian Potts and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, Art of the Western World, that focuses on art work from Cubism and abstract art and architecture to Surrealism. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the works of such artists as the Fauves, Pablo Picasso, Frank Lloyd Wright, Salvidor Dali and Joan Miro. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, intellectual and social context this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: A Fresh view: impressionism and post impressionism
results.creator_credit: Melissa Llewelyn-Davies and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on art work from the impressionists to the Post-Impressionists. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the works of such artists as Gustave Courbet, Georges Seurat, Vincent Van Gogh and Paul Cezanne, presenting the rejection of academic techniques that impressionism represented and its celebration of colour and light to the progression of these themes in the works of Post-Impressionism. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: The Classical idea
results.creator_credit: Bayley Silleck and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on the art of the Western classical world. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the origins of humanism and classical works of ancient Greece as well as Roman architecture and engineering. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
